text:
Okay, after nearly 31 years of cooking, my search for the "definitive" cranberry sauce recipe is over!  This recipe is fantastic!!  I doubled it, split the sugar between half white and half brown and added 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon (next time I will take that down to 1/4 teaspoon).  I cooked this for almost 20 minutes.  This was the best cranberry sauce I have ever had!  I used to just resort to canned because I never seemed to be able to make a "good" cranberry sauce.  Toni, thank you for sharing this recipe, it was another huge hit on our Thanksgiving table this past weekend.  (We had to celebrate early this year.)

text:
I mixed this recipe with another one I use.  I boiled the cranberries and sugar in 1/2 cup OJ and 1/2 cup unsweetened pineapple juice until they popped.  Then I added 6 oz. of fresh raspberries and mashed the whole thing.  Finally, I added 1/4 cup grand marinier, a 14 oz. can of crushed pineapple (drained), and some crushed peacans.  I cooked the mixture on medium heat until thickened, and refrigerated overnight.  Yum!

text:
This is so good!  I am a big fan of the canned jellied cranberry sauce, but now I am a convert.  Never again will I buy cranberry sauce, I will always make it.  This was so easy to make...and SO DELICIOUS!   And yes,cranberries do pop when boiled, so put the splatter guard on and let the kids listen.  I let them cook longer than 10 minutes just so it would get a little thicker, but after it is cooled it does thicken up more.  While they were boiling I gave them a good mash or two with my potato masher and the consistency was perfect.  Thank you Toni!

text:
I made this recipe this Thanksgiving, but changed it slightly.  I added about 1 tsp grated orange rind and after the berrys were cooked down I added about 1/8 cup of Grand Marinier. 

Not too many of my family like cranberries in any shape for form, but my nephew ( 13 years old ) loved it and asked to take some home.   I loved it and even put it on top of my oatmeal the next morning.   The juice was wonderful.  I would make it again.

text:
I was frantic for a quick and easy recipe as my other cranberry did not turn out as expected.  I chose this one.  As most of the reviewers pointed out, this was runny, but the flavor was great and the color was beautiful.  Adding a touch of grand marnier is ingenious. If you want a more gelled sauce, simply cut the OJ to 1/2 cup!  Once they start popping mash them with the back of a spoon.  This will gel in just a few hours in the fridge.  As it is, it is more of a delicious cranberry preserve - very spreadable for sandwiches!

text:
I have been making this for several years now and it is ALWAYS a huge hit at my Thanksgiving dinner! Even people who don't normally eat cranberry sauce seem to enjoy this. I have learned over the years a few little secrets to perfect this recipe... First, use half cup of white sugar and half cup of brown sugar. Second, add a few pinches of cinnamon to your desired taste. Other than those couple of things, make it as directed. It really couldn't be easier or any more delicious! Trust me, you will never go back to the canned junk again!!!

country:
None
text:
This is the best sauce.  I have been making this recipe with either orange juice, water or apple juice for the liquid.  The orange juice really makes it hands down the best.  For those who say it is too thin, cook it longer.  Cranberries have pectin in them.  The sauce naturally thickens the longer it cooks.  I have been known to overcook it an it be way too thick.  It can get as stiff as the stuff in the can and worse.  I cook until all the berries have popped and I have smooshed them against the edge of the pan.  Then it is perfect.

text:
This cranberry sauce is to die for. I have been making this recipe for years and will never use another. I add the fleshy part of one naval orange chopped with all white pith removed, stirring it in before cooling sauce at room temp. Brings this sauce from great to fantastic! It is impossible to mess up this recipe. I make thisup to 3 days in advance, it allows the flavors to blend and is one less thing that you will need to worry about on a busy day.

text:
I am so glad that I read the reviews and adjusted the recipe accordingly. I used 1/2cup orange juice, 1/2 cup water, 1/2 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar. I wasnt sure when I was supposed to add the cranberries, but I waited until the mixture was steaming, then added them. It seemed like it was taking a while for it to warm up, so I walked away and within 2 minutes my daughter ran outside to let me know the pot had boiled over. HUGE mess, so, don't walk away from this stuff (probably common sense to anyone else, but I dont cook much). It tastes AMAZING. I will NEVER buy canned cranberry sauce again.

text:
Spectacular celebration of the clean, tart flavor of cranberries. As noted, making it at least 24 hours in advance gives the orange flavor proper time to mellow and meld into the cranberries. The thickness is easily tailored to your tastes. Allow it to cook 3-5 minutes more for a thicker preparation. We did not find it to be overly sweet. A+ for the simple preparation, and gloriously fresh, uncomplicated flavor.

text:
This was really tasty, though after  reading some of the reviews,  did make a few changes. I only used 3/4 cup of orange juice, threw in about 1/2 cup of a frozen blueberry/raspberry/blackberry mixture, used 1/2 white and 1/2 brown sugar, 1/4 tsp. cinnamon and 1/2 tsp. vanilla. Let ths simmer about 15 min., mashing the berries with the back of a wooden spoon as they cooked. Let cool for a few minutes then added 1/8 cup of grand marnier. It was already quite thick when I put it in the refrgerator so I think it will be perfect for the big day tomorrow. Of course I had to taste it and it's already delicious, I can't wait to try it with the turkey. Definitely a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good cranberry sauce. I doctored it up a bit. I use 1 bag of cranberries, 1 cup of white sugar and 1 cup of water. While it's cooking I add 2 peeled oranges and 2 green-skinned apples (they have more pectin in them) cored but with the skins on. Granny Smith works best. After the cranberries have popped and the apples are completely cooked, I put the sauce through a ricer to remove the skins of the cranberries and apples. The pectin in the apples helps the sauce to thicken. My family loves it. It just wouldn't be Thanksgiving without it!

None
text:
This is a good "base" recipe that you can play around with to your liking in terms of sweetness, texture, etc. I took other reviewers' tips and adjusted the recipe as follows: I used half as much sugar as the recipe calls for and used both brown and white sugar.  I also used half water half OJ because as one reviewer mentioned, too much OJ will take away from the cranberry's tart flavor.  I also added a sache of cloves and removed it after I simmered saucefor about 20-30 minutes. I like mine smooth with a few cranberry lumps.

text:
Fantastic!! I haven't ever liked the "real" cranberry sauce my mother makes at holidays, (but I always ate a bit to be nice). I used half white and half brown sugar, and added 1/4 teaspoon of cinnamon. I also went through the berries before I put them in the pan, making sure to remove any stems. Nothing will ruin your enjoyment of a dish like a stray branch.  I am definitely a convert. I will probably not eat the canned stuff again!

None
text:
I've made this a few times, but I accidentally discovered a way to make these turn out smoother tasting and less tart.   My "accident" was that I forgot about the berries cooking in the juice and sugar on the stove. The sauce was very thick by this point. To compensate, I added 1/2 cup more orange juice and let it cook for a few more minutes. The result was a thick, rich, and smooth sauce with a deeply sweet flavor along with the slight tang and freshness of the extra orange juice. It turned out incredible!

text:
This recipe was so easy and turned out wonderfully.  However, the second time I made it, I cut the sugar to 3/4 C., which brightened the taste and allowed the fruit to stand on its own more.  I also doubled the cook time to 20 minutes to allow the sauce to thicken a bit more.  I now make it whenever fresh cranberries are available in the stores.

Really really delicious!  I too made some changes.  I took the advice of others and used 3/4 cup OJ and 1/4 Grand Marnier.  I used 3/4cup white sugar and 1/4 cup brown sugar.  I also added 1/4 tsp of cinnamon, 1/8 tsp nutmeg and two cloves.  I also added a handful of dehydrated onion.  FABULOUS!

text:
I haven't bought cranberry sauce in decades and found this to be the same as mine - so I love it.  I didn't give it 5 stars because of the OJ.  I agree about the calories but am also trying to minimize processed foods in our lives.  I would recommend juicing 1 or 2 CLEMENTINES into the water/sugar mix.  Zest a bit of the skin and you will absolutely love the taste, calories and the raves from the guests at your table.  I use this sauce year round, thus I freeze small portions for the roast chickens I do throughout the year.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!  This sauce tastes fantastic!  You will not be disappointed.  It has such a nice flavor.  The sauce really needs to be boiled, though, rather than just heated on medium.  Boiling it for the 10 minutes will cause all the berries to pop.  It will foam up but that will go away as it cools.  Just stir constantly while boiling.  It's worth it!!  Great idea to use the orange juice.

text:
So yummy!! Everyone liked it. I gave it 4 stars because it never settled for me, it was runny even after sitting all night in the fridge. I did use frozen cranberries may be that's why (edit I changed rating to 5 after I made this several times with fresh cranberries, the sauce settles just fine, no problems, but you do need to cook it longer, 15-20 minutes). Now I add gelatin (edit to frozen cranberries), we like jello like texture. I also took someone's advise and added a few raspberries (about 6-10 berries), and some cinnamon. Orange juice, raspberries, cinnamon give this jello outstanding flavor. I opened a can of cranberry sauce after this one was gone, it was absolutely horrible haha and we used to like it!!

text:
Not a cranberry sauce eater but thought I'd try homemade to see if it made a difference.  BOY does it!!!  I did modify based on other reviewers recommendations - used 1/4 c white sugar, 1/2 cup dark brown sugar, and a DASH of cinnamon at the end.  The molasses in the brown sugar helps to mellow the OJ and the cinnamon just brings it all together.  I think I'll try it with apple juice next time just for kicks :)

This seemed like the perfect recipe. Then I tasted it. I do not care for cooked orange juice, I think it tastes musty. On the plus side: I figured out the mystery "yuck" ingredientt that appears is some mulled wine recipes :o) I dumped in more sugar and boiled until pretty thick then swirled in maybe 1/4 c. Of fresh OJ when I took it off the heat. Yum!  I guess my perfect recipe will be 12 oz cranberries boiled with 1 c sugar & 1/2 c water. Then add 1/2 cold oj and chilled. Yum! Well maybe more sugar? We use it as a spread for cold turkey sandwiches.

text:
First batch I made exactly as directed. It was runny and a little too tart tasting (but still very good). For the second batch, I took the suggestion of only using a half cup of OJ and it turned out absolutely delicious but it gelled a little too much. Now I'm working on batch number 3. I used a little more than 1/2 cup but not quite 3/4 cup orange juice and I'm hoping it'll be just right.
Also, definitely use fresh squeezed orange juice to get that super fresh taste. Concentrated OJ makes it too sweet and kind of "preserved" tasting.

text:
This recipe is so simple. My boyfriend gave me "Mom's advise" cook it until you hear it popping and then once the popping seems to slow down take it off the heat & cool. We added cinnamon, and clove (maybe 1/8) to taste. Keep it in the background flavor- that spice that you just can't put your finger on. I also did half white/half brown sugar since I'm trying to find ways to use up the 5lb bag I bought.

this was wonderful and soooooooooo easy! i used 1c sugar and 1/2 c brn sugar and 16oz fresh cranberries. i also only used 1/2 oj and 1/2 water but think next time i will use more oj because i liked the way it cut the tartness of the cranberries. i also added a dash of cinnamon. yum!! be careful though cause this will boil over real quick! i went 2 get the remote to change the chanel and heard it boiling over right then! yummy! no more store bought for me!

text:
This is an excellent basic cranberry sauce.  In the past, I always made a version with nuts and apples in it, but my family doesn't care for it, and I end up eating it all myself.  This year I decided to try something different.  The only changes I made were I added some grated orange zest and about 1/4 tsp of cinnamon (because I saw Tyler Florence make a similar version yesterday on Food Network, and he used a cinnamon stick & grated orange zest).  Excellent!  I highly recommend.

text:
This has been my absolute favorite recipe for several years. Am asked to bring it just about everywhere over the holidays.  The recipe I was given is only slightly different - it calls for 2 slightly under ripe PEARS!  I don't bother will peeling them..just core and cut into medium chunks. The orange zest polishes it off nicely..I make it several says in advance (or not..if I can't stay out of it)  Always make more than you think you need..it never lasts.  It's great on oatmeal, cottage cheese..goes well with fish,too. Best thing is that it will keep in fridge almost indefinitely! Whenever I can find fresh cranberries...I love to make it..not just for the holidays. Bon apetit!

text:
Ooh LA LA! Have made this recipe for years! It only gets better. The reviews are always wonderful! I've tweaked the recipe as such (really like the cranberry flavor & orange to "pop" together in your mouth): one 12 oz bag cranberries, 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1/3 cup white sugar,  3/4 cup OJ, 1/4 cup water (+/-), zest of one orange, and 1/2 cup chopped walnuts. Cook about 15-18 minutes. You'll never go back to canned cranberries again!!!   Thank you Toni for sharing!

country:

text:
This was my 1st cranberry relish I've made and it was a HUGE hit with everyone on Christmas! I used "most pulp" OJ, and based on some of the other reviews I made the following changes:
*Cooked it a bit longer ( about 20 mins ) 
*Mashed the cranberries to get a thicker consistency
*Added a dash of cinnamon to taste.
It turned out delish! I was worried it would be a bit tart, and when I make it again I might add about .25 cup more sugar but everyone else raved that the sweetness balanced perfectly w/the tartness. Depends on taste I guess! I def recommend - Easy and very quick to make. So much better than store bought - I'm a convert!

Everyone really enjoyed this and all agreed it is much much better than the canned stuff. Like other reviewers I only used 3/4 cup of  o.j. then cooked mine a bit longer and then strained it because I know some of my picky eaters don't like whole berry sauce. I'm glad I made the day before because it seemed to get better every day - it was extremly tart when first made but the tartness mellowed overnight.

text:
After being married 43 years, I decided to try my hand at homemade cranberry sauce this year.  I looked through Allrecipes.com for a recipe and chose this one.  I just finished making it this morning so I could "test it out" -- that would give me time to buy more canned sauce if need be -- but OH MY!  This is so simple and absolutely the best sauce ever!  The only thing I did differently was to add a big spoonful of orange marmalade while cooking the cranberries.  Made a generous bowl full and I bet we'll eat it all!  I can't wait for my husband to taste it.  Thanks for this recipe Toni.  Bye bye canned sauce!

text:
Very good!  I've never made cranberry sauce with OJ before, I really liked it!  Unlike others, I DO like canned cranberry sauce and this isn't a sub for it, any more than baked homemade mac and cheese is a sub for the blue box.  It's a completely different thing!  I used fresh orange juice, and zested the orange into the mixture as well.  I also added a sprinkle of cinnamon.  I would be very cautious about changing/lessening the amount of sugar here, if you're going to do that do it well enough in advance to be able to add more if needed.  I used the full amount of sugar and mine was very tart. Just a great recipe, and one we'll make again!

The orange juice is a great idea, my family loved it today.  I'd like to add that you need to cook the sauce until all the berries pop, not just until they start popping.  Otherwise it'll be too soupy as not all of the thickening goodness will escape from the fruit.

I made per the recipe before I made edits and as written, it's still 5 stars. However, to cater to my family's taste, here's what I did:
Instead of 1 c of white sugar, I used 1/4 c white sugar and 1/4 c brown sugar. 
I added the zest from one orange and 1/2 t cinnamon with the cranberries. 
When I took the sauce off the heat, I added about 2 T of Grand Marnier.

This sauce is SO GOOD.

Display Name:
BellaSouth

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this for Thanksgiving tomorrow, but I wish I had doubled the recipe - maybe even tripled.  After the cranberries "cook down," there's barely enough for 4 people - and there will be 10 people here tomorrow.  Kind of a hassle to make more, but maybe there will be a couple of folks who don't care for cranberry sauce.  

That said, the sauce tastes wonderful, but only because I changed a few things.  Like others, I substituted half of the sugar for brown and made the total sugar about 1/2 cup rather than a cup.  I also added a healthy pinch of good-quality cinnamon and a pinch of salt.  Finally, I allowed the berries to simmer for a total of 20 minutes so they would thicken.  

And for heaven sake, people, quit obsessing about sugar for one day a year, okay?  So no dessert at your house either?  I'm glad I won't be part of your crowd.  Mainly, however, the sauce is NOT too sweet  if you follow my recipe.  Cranberries are very very tart and the sugar is necessary.

text:
When I 1st made this, I was tasting the moment it came off the stove. And knowing I used SPLENDA(R) in place of the sugar, I expected to be just a tad tart but it was severely tart. At least when biting into the cranberries it's self(right after making it). However, I cooled and placed in the frig for a few days, and then it seemed the flavors worked their magic and tasted way better after I let sit and the cranberries were not as tart as they previously were.. It's totally worth a few days to wait on the best flavor.

country:
None
text:
Because of how large my family is, I have to double this recipe but I made a couple of small changes to help reduce the sweetness and acidity. Instead of 2 cups of white sugar, I use 1.5 cups white sugar and .5 cups of brown sugar. Instead of 2 cups of orange juice I use 1.5 cups of orange juice and .5 cups of water. This is double the servings and it might not seem like much of a change but the first time I tried this recipe, I followed it to the letter and, even though everybody liked it, it was too sweet. At Christmas the same same year, I made it how I described above and everyone loved it. I'm no longer allowed to tamper with the recipe! :)

None
text:
My husband is diabetic, so I used 24 Splenda packets, which equals 1 cup sugar.  The packets were all I had at the time, but you could use the bag of Splenda as well.  I used a Cran-grape juice, but you could use any kind of juice and mix with water, 1/2 cup juice + 1/2 cup water, or use a diet juice instead.  Before these alterations, my husband couldn't touch this yummy, once-in-a-while condiment.  These changes reduce the calories and carbs making it possible for him to not feel like he's missing out.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have never made cranberry sauce before, and this is the first recipe I came accross. Not only was it EXTREMELY easy, it tasted perfect.
This is exactly how I like my cranberry sauce!
The only things I noted for next time were that it was a little runny at first, and even after sitting for a while I think I could have used just a tiny tiny bit less juice? But the next day after it being in my fridge, it was perfectly textured.
And I had to turn my heat to high to get the berries to really pop, and I cooked a tad longer... maybe fifteen minutes.
(Could be my stove)
:)

This recipe is awesome.  It is so easy and quick why would anyone ever buy canned cranberries again.  I did use about 3/4 cup of juice instead of a full cup because other reviews said it was runny.  It was seriously my favorite dish at thanksgiving this year and it was so easy that my 5 year did the whole thing except measure the juice and sugar.  One tip to others is if you like it a bit sweeter or it seems too tart just and a little honey to taste while it is still warm.  Great recipe!!!

text:
This is a great, simple cranberry sauce. It is quick and easy and has NO corn syrup! I followed someone else's review of using only a 1/2 cup of orange juice to help thicken the consistency. It works perfectly! I normally buy the organic canned cranberry sauce, and this recipe is a bit more tart. I may cut the orange juice with water next time so it won't be as tart, but it probably depends more on the type of OJ you have. Overall, an excellent and easy recipe. I ate some while it was cooling in the bowl!

Display Name:
Carole

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this but I also modified it.  Instead of using orange juice, I used mandarin juice, and when the sauce was done and cooled off I mixed in the drained mandarin slices.   Mandarins complement well w/ cranberries (they are not bitter whatsoever), and it makes a very pretty dish to see the mandarin slices peeking thru the red cranberry sauce.  I used 1/2 cup white sugar, and 1/2 cup brown sugar, and a pinch of cinnamon.  I won't ever buy canned cranberries again.  This was the easiest, most relaxing, enjoyable dish I've made for Thanksgiving.  I didn't even have to mash the cranberries at all.   I didn't want any whole, raw cranberries in it, so I let it boil a couple more minutes until the last of the whole cranberries popped.

Very good and simple!
I cut the sugar in half and use half orange juice/half water, and I add a dash of cinnamon and a tablespoon of rum.

text:
There is absolutely no reason to buy canned cranberry sauce when this recipe is so easy and so delicious. Takes almost no time to make and could easily feed a large family during Thanksgiving. For an extra kick, I added orange zest and a dash of cinnamon. For a less intensely sweet flavor, use brown sugar instead of white, or use 3/4 cup white sugar. I have made this every year for the past five years and everyone loves it. Thanks so much!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This cranberry sauce is almost easier than opening a can.  It's a great basic recipe to work from.  I've used juice from clementines and it's great.  Add some zest, add some brandy or red wine, add some hot pepper flake (just one shake, seriously it doesn't make it spicy, just gives it a zing.  try it), sub in some honey for sugar.   This stuff is great on brie wrapped in phyllo.  It's great with cream cheese, ice cream. I made it too runny once and poured some of the juice off into glasses and added seltzer, that was great.  Really, no need to buy the junk in the can at all.  Eat real food.

So glad I did, because I have a feeling this will be eaten all up in a heartbeat for tomorrow's Thanksgiving feast! Slight changes I made: I used 1/2 white sugar and 1/2 brown sugar. Also, cut down on OJ just a tad. Added about a tsp of cinnamon during cooking. Will put in fridge overnight. Thanks for the crazy good recipe Toni !! No more cans! "Stay away from the cans! He hates these cans!!" (Scene from The Jerk)..

I have been making this recipe for the last several Thanksgivings/Christmases and it is always a hit!  I have never before eaten cranberry sauce as a snack, but this is so wonderful, I can't stop eating it!  I like to cook it a little longer, so the cranberries are nice and soft, and I also like to add a pinch of cinnamon for a bit extra flavor.  I also find that this sauce gets better after sitting in the fridge for a day or two, but that is hard to do, because everytime I open the fridge door, I'm sneaking spoonfuls out of the bowl!

I am going to rate this recipe as is. I hate it when people rate the recipe after they have made changes to it. So, I think this is almost perfect. I think the sugar should definately be cut back to 1/2 and when I made it a second time I added a small dash of cinammon and a splash of Grand Marnier and it was superb. Also, some reviewers stated they did not know when the cranberries popped. Unless you are blind you can definately tell when they pop. Overall a keeper and we will finally replace the canned cranberries we have every year.

userID:
2585501
Display Name:
Chris Bauer
isPro:
False
followersCount:
25

0

6

32

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1336015.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my first pass at this recipe and scratch-made cranberry sauce, and I love it. However, I did what I almost never do and made changes on the first try, mainly because of what I'd read in other reviews I made a triple batch of this. You better have plans for this after T-Day if you do this. It is a huge pot of loveliness. 

I used 1/2 to 2/3 of the amount of white sugar. I used only a third of a cup of brown sugar, the zest of one whole orange, added two teaspoons of clover honey, a tablespoon or so of salted butter, and a few pinches of cinnamon, to taste. It's just now cooling in a bowl and I can't tell you how excited I am for the family to try this sweet-tart version, close in flavor to lingonberries, which we love.

...looking forward to trying a little Grand Marnier with it sometime in the future.

UPDATE: My whole family raved about this stuff and are beggin for the recipe. We ate it everyday on our oatmeal (which I already add raisins, sliced almost, cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla to), and I have to make more because we're out and now addicted.

text:
This is a great basic recipes. I use half the sugar and prefer it tart and less calories. Additions Ive made over years include cooking with a cinnamon stick, adding a touch of cinnamon, using maple syrup to sweeten,  grate in fresh orange zest and adding walnut pieces when finished cooking and more cooled down (a favorite addition!). You can tweak the basic recipe and not mess it up much. I also use 1-10oz individual serving bottle of OJ for thicker sauce. Mash cranberries to desired consistency. Huge hit all around, enjoy all throughout holiday season!.

country:
None
text:
Close watch on the Cooking time is the key to making it the perfect consistency.  I boiled the mixture- full boil.  Then turned it down to LO and cooked for exactly 10 minutes.  Then smashed up the berries and let sit out on the counter until it cooled (about 2 hours).  Then I refrigerated and it was perfect!

Side note, I have cooked it before and the berries were slightly larger and required an extra 5 minutes.  The key is:  if the berries easily mash it is done- if not wait until they are.

text:
Great basic recipe to start from. I used 1/2 cup of pineapple juice, 1 pured orange, 1 cinnamon stick, zest from half the orange, and reduced the sugar just a little, using 1/2 brown and 1/2 white. It thickened up nicely after about 45 minutes and I had to help some of the cranberries along as they still hadn't popped by the end. Make sure you stir once in awhile, especially once it starts thickening; mine started sticking a bit. I'm planning on serving over a block of Neufchtel cheese with crackers.

Display Name:
BrownLuster

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was phenominal as it was easy to prepare! I doubled the recipe and used 1 cup Tropicana Grovestand OJ with 1 cup of natural pineapple juice (drained the juice from a 20 oz. can of Dole pineapple chucks) as my liquid base and used 1 cup of Sugar and 1 cup of Light Brown Sugar.  I also added 1/8 teaspoon of Orange zest. I followed one reviewers recommendation to cover the pot with a splatter shield. The cranberries gently popped opened and they were an absolute beautiful combination of chunky, almost whole berries and a nicely thickened jelly. The doubled recipe made a little over 6 cups (50 oz). Based on the many reviews, the sweetness of the cranberry sauce intensifies the longer it stays cooled in the fridge, so with that in mind I poured the Cranberry Sauce nto a small Corningware casserole dish, covered it and let it sit in the fridge two days before Thanksgiving day. When it was time to serve, I broke it up a bit with a spoon before scooping it out into a fancy serving dish and garnished it with a small sprig of Rosemary in the middle. The sauce received Oooos & Ahhhhs just before it was gobbled up!! Needless to say, the Ocean Spray stayed in the can and will stay on the grocery store shelf from now on. Lol!!

An easy and excellent go-to recipe!!

I will NEVER buy canned cranberry sauce again!  I will NEVER serve Thanksgiving dinner without this recipe!  I plan to make this for other upcoming social events. this recipe is fabulous and easy.  My only concern is finding real cranberries year-round.  The presentation is beautiful.  I recommend that you do not mash the berries at all. text:
I am not a big fan of cranberry sauce, but my family likes it, so... it has to be done. I just can't bring myself to try the can-shaped thing, so I tried out this recipe a few years ago. It is pretty good, and family likes it, so it is a win. The only thing I do differently is that once the sugar is dissolved, I turn the heat very low, and let it cook slowly for about an hour. I check on it every 5-10 minutes or so, to stir and smoosh the cranberries. It's also one of those things you can make a few days ahead, to alleviate the cooking load on the actual holiday.
Review:
Rating:

userID:
8049402
Display Name:
calimom

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You can achieve kid-approved (and can-shaped cranberry jelly loving in-laws) homemade cranberry sauce with this recipe by simply straining the cooked sauce through a strainer while hot, pressing the pulp to be sure to get everything (I strain it into my serving dish and refrigerate overnight). It comes out perfect EVERY time, and I've been making this recipe for 4 years. A couple of tips: you must cook this way past the "popping stage" to achieve a smooth and jelled sauce. Cook until the sauce becomes dark red through and through and begins to thicken on its own. I also add about a 1/4 cup more sugar to cut the tartness for my kids. The first year I made this, my mother-in-law still brought a can of cranberry sauce thinking she and my father-in-law wouldn't like it, but it was a hit. No more can-shaped cranberry jelly at our Thanksgiving table! (I've also doubled the recipe and at times added the Grand Mariner - perfect and delish!)

Had to make this a little different then the recipe calls for. Could not find fresh cranberries so went with dried. Went with 1 1/2 cups orange juice and a splash of water. Next time think I will put it in the blender then chill for a few hours in a jello mold to get that jelly likeness that she enjoys.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe. I used half brn sug/white sug and had to cook it way longer than instructed to get it to hold its shape a bit. I'd encourage all to rinse the fresh cranberries in a strainer and pick out the leaves and mushy ones. Maybe it's common sense to some, but this was my first time making cranberry sauce and I nearly just threw the cranberries in straight from the bag. I was surprised how many yucky ones there were. Also, the longer I let it cook, the richer the flavor became. Can't wait to dig in tomorrow! Happy Thanksgiving everyone!

Made this for Thanksgiving today. Soooo good. I did the half brown sugar, half white sugar and doubled the recipe. I added a little cinnamon (about 1/2 teaspoon) and it gave it just a little extra flavor. It is sooooo good. I don't normally care for the canned cranberry sauce, but I didn't want to stop eating this one. I had to seal it in my canning jars to keep away from it.  Definately will make it again. Super easy, took about 15 minutes from start to finish. I used a potato masher to smash the cranberries for a smoother consistency.

I concur with other reviewers: use half white sugar and half brown sugar. It was a little runny, so I now use extra pulp orange juice and cook it for about 5 extra minutes, and now it's perfect. Best to make it the day of or the day before, because the longer it sits it starts to lose some of the cranberry tang and gets sweeter.

I have always liked the canned cranberry sauce but I have seen the light!  I made this recipe last year and it was a huge hit and I will be making it again on Thursday.  It is perfect as-is.  If you want it a little less chunky, I'd recommend squeezing the berries against the edge of the pan with your spoon/spatula/whatever to smush them.  I probably cooked it for longer than 10 minutes doing that but it didn't suffer for it.  Delicious!

When prepared as written, the result was the consistency of simple syrup, even after refrigerating overnight. I dumped it back into a saucepan and simmered it for a couple of hours (which was probably overkill), then popped it back into the fridge for an hour, and the final result was as thick as the whole berry canned variety and delicious to boot! Next time, I'll try halving the orange juice amount as suggested by other comments.

This recipe has a fantastic flavor.  I used fresh-squeezed orange juice and organic cane sugar.  Definitely cook it longer than 10 minutes.  Mine was somewhat watery.  Could be the altitude here in Ft. Collins, but next time I'll cook it until it thickens somewhat in the pan before I let it sit.

text:
Very Delicious. I only give it 4 stars since I tweeked some. I followed some reviews of others and did a 1/2 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup light brown sugar. And at the end of the cooking period I sprinkled some cinnamon over the top and stirred it in as well. I, like others, feel I will never go back to canned sauce again. I agree it makes a great spread on the yeast rolls as well. I did cook and stir mine at least 10 minutes longer to get a noticeably thicker sauce. I just hope I find cranberries through out the year as this needs to be eaten year round!

text:
I am not a big fan of reviews of recipes that have been altered because it doesn't really give a review of the original recipe. That being said, I didn't have any orange juice when I started making this recipe, but I did have some "Cuties". I peeled three of these little guys, and boiled them in about 1/4 cup of water. After removing the casings, I peeled another one, cut it up and threw it in. This seemed to make a great substitute for the orange juice, and the final result was amazing.

I made the recipe with 1/2 c brown and 1/2 c white sugar and  the 1 c orange juice. I Simmered it for the recomended 10 minutes. It's still warm and I cant keep my spoon out of it. It's thickening as it cools and the berries mashed up nicely. Sweet then tart flavor, I LOVE IT. I made it today because I wanted a trial run before I set the table for 20 people on Thanksgiving Day. I will definately make a bowl of this cranberry sauce and i'll also have on hand some canned sauce for the die hards.  I'm going to try grape juice the next time, has anyone tried that?

text:
I've made this recipe for years but through the years have wanted more so in my experimentation, I have ended up doubling the recipe (there's never enough for the sandwiches and take home for guests. I also add a splash of vanilla, grated orange zest and the juice of 2 oranges (grand marnier can be expensive and the zest n juice does well in a pinch) and about 1 tsp of honey which gives it a little more depth and richness. Great as it is, but fun to experiment. Everyone loves it.

I don't like a lot of citrus in my cranberry sauce and so I used 1/2 cup orange juice and 1/2 cup water. I also used a hand held blender leaving about half of the berries whole. It turned out totally fabulous.

text:
I tried this after reading through many of the reviews and made a few of the suggested adjustments.  I used 1/2 C orange juice, 1/2 C pineapple juice, and 1/2 granulated and 1/2 brown sugar. I had pineapple chunks so after draining the juice, I pureed about 1/2 C in the blender and cooked it with the cranberries, added a little allspice and 1/4 t cinnamon.  It is the best I have ever tasted.

None
text:
I have made this recipe three years in a row. I love it because it's quick, easy, and tasty. The cranberries are so pretty with the varying reds. Then all you need is sugar (I did half brown and half red) and orange juice, which I always have on hand. Some people add spices (like cinnamon), and I tried this one year, but I prefer the simple version of orange and cranberry. Add a little orange (or clementine!) zest on top and it's a perfect Thanksgiving side dish.

text:
Best cranberry sauce I've ever had. Made it exactly as described. I would suggest making it the day before and letting it cool and set up in the fridge overnight. It has a brighter, more intense orange flavor when you first make it but the orange mellows a bit by the next day. I love it! It's fresh and delicious and the cranberries are tender and chewy. I'll never buy canned again.

text:
This is really good...however, the first batch I made was runny like a few other comments.  So I made a second batch, used 1/2 c oj only and added about a tsp of jello, once it started boiling even on simmer, I added my 'runnier' batch, some vanilla and 3 cloves.  Cooked for 15 minutes and know I have a nice consistency and GRAND cranberry 'sauce'.  I would have used plain gelatin if I had it, but only had strawberry.  Still a big hit with the family.

text:
Thank you for this recipe! I don't generally care for cranberry sauce, but this was delicious! My mother-in-law loved it!  It was a bit thinner than I expected, but after years of tinned sauce I don't think I knew just what to expect!
UPDATE: made this again this year and it is even better than I remembered! The key is letting the cranberries boil for quite some time... I think I left them for 20 minutes! The longer they simmer, the thicker it gets!

text:
I read many reviews before making and reduced the amount of orange juice to about   cup and  balanced with water. I also did a 50/50 with brown sugar and regular granulated sugar. When I first made it I thought it had a really strong citrus flavor and I didnt like it but the next afternoon I tried it at Thanksgiving it had really balanced out and was a huge hit. I love that you can make this a few days ahead. I recommend making this the day before for flavor.

Display Name:
KitchenDiva

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/490340.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This sauce is pretty delicious, although it is VERY sweet! I suspected it was going to be sweet, so I used 1/2c. brown sugar and 1/4c. white sugar, and also reduced the orange juice by 1/4c. Still pretty sweet. I'm not sure if I just had particularly sweet cranberries or what, but if you're looking for a tart and tangy sauce, this isn't the one for you! Aside from the sweetness, the taste is really very good and it set up nicely. I put half the batch in the foodprocessor for a couple of pulses and mashed the rest with the back of a spoon for a nice consistency.  Also added 1/4tsp. of cinnamon and 1tb. of Galliano. It was really good...I think I might add a little lemon or orange zest just to cut the sweetness a little.  It does seem like it would be amazing on toast or muffins though...like a yummy cranberry jam!

text:
Great recipe for those that like the canned cranberry sauce!  My husband loves (or thought he did) the canned stuff, but I still wanted to try to make it from scratch.  I doubled the recipe and added an additional cup of white sugar and cup of orange juice.  I don't recommend this step unless you have a sweet tooth.  I took out about 2 cups of cranberries (once they were cooked) and the juice and pureed it.  I then added it back to the rest of the dish.  It turned out wonderful!  My husband admits that he liked it a lot better than the canned stuff!

I followed the other reviewers, adding 1/4 tsp cinnamon and splitting the 1 cup sugar between white and brown sugar. Considering that my family and I never go near cranberry sauce, everyone tried it this year and enjoyed it. I even spooned some over "Aunt Johnnie's Pound Cake" that I got off of this site, which is a real triumph for cranberries everywhere. My only complaint is that it's not as thick as I was expecting. Maybe next time I'll add some flour or corn starch to give it a thicker consistency.

text:
So easy that I agree with others- no need to buy the canned stuff again.  I added 1/4 tsp. cinnamon which I thought was a nice touch.  I simmered for about 12 min.  Don't obsess over the time- just keep simmering and stir every couple of minutes until they are the consistency you like.    I recommend making the day before and refrigerating overnight.  They set up nicely this way.

city:

country:
None
text:
5 Stars for this cranberry sauce!  I will NEVER buy canned again, it's just that good.  This was super easy, and set up just like the jelled canned version, only tastes 100% better!  The orange juice, rather than water like other recipes, really makes the difference here.  Per other reviews, I made in advance on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving to let the flavors blend together.  My mother in law was so impressed with this, she went home with the recipe...and that's saying a LOT! My husband was licking it off the spoon right out of the pan! The cranberries do "pop" as they soften, and I used my potato masher to mash them but left some of the berries only half mashed to give it a good texture.  Perfect!  Thanks so much for this recipe, I will continue to use it and make people think I slaved!  :)

region:

country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt to make cranberry sauce. It was amazingly simple and delicious. I spent only 15 minutes in front of the stove! I am now wondering why ever bothered to eat canned cranberry sauce. 

Some reviewers have said it was too runny. So I cut the orange juice down to 1/2 a cup. However, I soon found it needed more liquid. I added another 1/4 cup to thin it out. So personally, I would put the whole cup of juice into the sauce at the start, and then keep it on the heat until it reaches the desired consistency.

text:
For perfect "jelly": use 1/4 c. Grand Marnier, 3/4 c. OJ, 1 c. white sugar, a pinch of cinnamon, pinch of ginger. Cook for 25-30 mins. mashing berries while they cook. Press through sieve or wire strainer. Firms up nicely and is delicious! Thanks for the start! This is a keeper!

text:
I just made this recipe for the second year in a row, and had forgotten how good it is! I can't believe I served the canned cranberries for so long; they are nothing like the real thing in this recipe! It's the perfect combination of sweet and tart. I cooked it for 15 minutes and also helped along the process with a potato masher. I hadn't started it in enough time, so when it cooled off slightly, I put it in the freezer for about a half hour to speed the cooling process, then transferred it to the fridge.  Thanks for this simple but tasty recipe!

What I like about this recipe is it can be used as a base for modification. In place of the orange juice, I used another juice high in antioxidants, Pomegranate juice! While it cools add 1/4 cup of orange cognac. Chill in frig for a day. My husband likes it just by itself during the cold and flu season...about 1/4 cup a day. In most regions cranberries are only sold during the holidays; so I stock up and keep the packages in the freezer.

text:
I love this basic recipe, though I do like to add some orange zest. I also like to take this basic recipe and expand on it to make it my own, but the basic recipe just as it's written is excellent. Just sweet enough, with a little tang. My 4 year old started asking for it as soon as he saw the bags of cranberries in our refrigerator last week and has been counting the days until Thanksgiving just so he can have cranberries. I like to take some of the leftovers, puree it in a food processor, and add some brown sugar and cinnamon to make kind of a "syrup" for waffles and pancakes, and I also love it added along with brown sugar and cinnamon to oatmeal. It is also wonderful served alongside orange muffins.

text:
This was very easy, but I cooked it much longer than instructed.  I added a 1/4 cup of Grand Marnier.  My sugar was 1/2 cup white and 1/2 cup of brown.  I  split the recipe into a berry cranberry and a jelled version.  I put 1/2 of it in the blender and pureed the mix.  This did make it a bit more tart than we like, so I put the pureed 1/2 back on the stove with more oj and brown sugar.

text:
Never was a big fan of cranberry sauce, but after seeing all the reviews, I had to try this!  I picked and chose some adjustments based on comments.  1/2 cup white sugar and 1/2 cup brown sugar used (instead of the full 1 cup of white sugar) and 1/4 tsp of cinnamon.  It came out so good!  Definitely on the sweeter side and reminiscent of a pie filling.  Tasted amazing with the rest of Thanksgiving dinner, and I have so many ideas of what to do with the leftovers!

text:
I think maybe this wasn't as wonderful for me as it was for others since I had to make a large serving (50 people for Thanksgiving-ugh!). Very glad I made it ahead of time.  I had tripled the recipe and hesitated about using all OJ, but the reviews were so enthusiastic, I went for it.  In the large quantity, the orange came through very strongly and not in a good way.  I ended up scooping out half of it and making another batch using plain water, and then mixed that in. Then it was wonderful, and none to take home!

text:
Made this last year with some alterations based on reviews. It was great! But I can't remember what I did...

This year, I used 3/4 c OJ and 1/4 Grand Marnier. 1/2 c white sugar and 1/2 c brown sugar. I also put a pinch of nutmeg and 2-3 pinches of cinnamon. Accidentally bought an 8 oz bag of cranberries instead of 12 oz, so I removed 1/4 c of liquid before putting cranberries in.

Flavor was good. Too sweet, so I probably could have removed a little more liquid and adjusted the sugar/OJ ratio for the smaller bag of cranberries. I think it would have been perfect if I had used the correct amount of cranberries.

I like this recipe, but I make a few simple changes to turn it into one I love!  I only use 2/3 the sugar because the orange juice adds sugar as well.  At the end after I turn the heat off, I add about 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon and 1/8 teaspoon of almond extract.  It is even good on ice cream!

userID:
26525015
Display Name:
Riley Warren
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7333979.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this as written last year and everyone really liked it. I find it to be a great base recipe for cranberry sauce. This year I decided to up the game a little. I reduced the orange juice to 3/4 cup + 1/4 cup water and simmered it with the sugar as directed. I added the 12oz bag of fresh cranberries and let them go at it for about 5 minutes, then I added a couple handfuls of blueberries. Toward the end, I added 2 tbsp orange juice concentrate + 1/2 tsp orange extract (this is a substitute for grand marnier, as we dont really drink alcohol and I dont cook enough sweet dishes to justify buying a $19 bottle of liquor). I let it all simmer together for a couple more minutes and then stuck it in a dish to cool. I have to say, it is SO good. The blueberries really help cut the tartness of the cranberries and even my 4 year old loves the sauce, and she normally doesnt like cranberries because of how puckering they can be. Im going to keep this version around for next year!
Review:
Rating:
5

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my very first attempt at homemade cranberry sauce and I nailed it! It was so unbelievably easy and is still delicious 3 days later! I followed most reviewers suggestions to use half OJ half water and half white sugar and half brown. I was surprised how quickly the berries popped. I simmered them for 10 min then mashed against side of pan then simmered an additional 5 min. The consistency is nice but not very gelatinous. If you prefer thicker then simmer an extra 5-10 min. I cant wait to serve this to my guests at Thanksgiving Dinner!

text:
Double the recipe, split the sugar between half white and half brown and add 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon. Can let cook an extra 10 min for thicker product. While they are boiling give them a good mash or two with potato masher for perfect consistency. For a little more flavor, add only 3/4 of a cup of orange juice and after it is cooked add 1/4 cup of Grand Marnier.

userID:
24759053
Display Name:
badcrc
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this to put in fridge for Christmas Eve dinner.  I've made a variation with 50/50 orange juice and water before.  I had 2lbs of cranberries so I made the following tweaks:
2lbs Cranberries, washed
20oz orange juice (not covering cranberries, about an inch below coverage)
3/4 cup white sugar
3/4 cup dark brown sugar
1-1.5 tsp grated orange zest (using microplane aka fine grater)
1/2 tsp nutmeg
1/2 tsp cinnamon

Brought to a boil in a wide pot, then lowered to med-high and continued to lower temp as it thickened, continuing to low boil until it was getting close to the thickness I wanted then I used a potato masher in the pot as it cooked.  Once it got thick I turned off heat and let it cool.  Very thick and great taste.  It has a slight sweetness but still tart, sort of like a marmalade, which I like.  Lots of orange flavor so if you don't want that I would use half water and half orange juice and leave out the orange zest which is what I did last year and that gives just a hint of orange flavor.

userID:
21087341
Display Name:
Love to Cook
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

8

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent!  Don't be intimidated.  This is a really easy recipe.  Puts store bought jellied cranberry sauce to shame, and has no bad ingredients in it.    I didn't have any OJ, so used water and added a bit of orange oil that I use for baking.  Based on other reviews, I used 1/2 white, and 1/2 brown cane sugar, although used a little less than 1c because I don't care for super sweet.  Balanced out the tartness of the cranberries nicely.   Hand mashed it, but if your a "texture person", you could easily place in a blender (be careful if the mixture is hot when you do this!)  Added about 1/8c of Grand Marnier, and instead of cinnamon, I grated some fresh nutmeg.  The sauce sets up nicely, and makes a nice home made gift, which is what I am doing with the jars.

text:
I really liked this recipe because of it's simplicity. Delicious!

I had never bought fresh cranberries before. I thought they were like other berries so I brought home a 3 pound bag. Well after biting in to a few different shades of them I realized they are most definitely NOT like other berries! So I came looking for a recipe where I wouldn't need to buy many new ingredients.

This cranberry recipe was exactly what I needed! We ended up putting this on top of our panna cotta for Thanksgiving. In other batches we also mixed in strawberries, kiwis, bananas and it works really well with everything! 

Thank you for sharing this with us!

text:
This is an incredible recipe. My family absolutely loves it, In fact, I made it for 2018 Thanksgiving and by popular request, a second batch the next day to go with leftovers!! I split between brown and white sugar. I also add 1 Granny Smith apple and reduce about 10 minutes longer than the recipe calls for. A fun thing to do is use a bundt cake mold and place in the fridge. Once set just set the mold in a hot water bath to loosen from the mold and turn upside down onto a plate. I garnish with orange zest.

So good!  Followed the recipe as is, just mashed the berries with the back of a spoon as the sauce was cooking.  This thickened beautifully and the flavor got even better after sitting in the fridge for awhile.  I mixed some of the leftovers with softened butter to put on our cranberry walnut bread, and it was amazing.  Can't wait to find more uses for this sauce!

text:
Best Cranberry sauce recipe out there that I've tried. The orange juice really gives this a much more rounded flavor instead of just using water like many recipes do. I've taken it to several work and friends Thanksgiving events over the last few years, and there's rarely any left.

A few slight changes that I make to it. First, I swap out a quarter cup of the OJ for bourbon/Jack Daniels (just needs to be the "big bottle" whiskey, nothing particularly special). Second, I add about 1-1.5 tsp of good cinnamon to the sauce once its finished.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is definitely great, however take a look at possibly making these simple changes.

When you begin dissolving your sugar in the orange juice

1.  Add 2 cinnamon sticks

2.  Use a fresh orange, first grate off about 2 tablespoons of zest before squeezing the juice from the orange

3.  After adding the cranberries and when the cooking portion is done, remove the cinnamon sticks and begin crushing the cranberries.  

4.  When the cranberries are crushed refigerate.  After the cranberry sauce is cooled off, add the orange zest to the top of the dish.  This will add a nice color and additional flavor.

I realized as I was prepared to make this recipe that I did not have an orange juice in the refrigerator--with some trepidation, I substituted the orange juice with apple cider--you know I thought about cran-apple....so I took a risk.  I also did add in a couple table spoons of lemon juice and 1/3 cup light brown sugar.  And let me say, It's the best cranberry sauce I've ever tasted!  Nothing like what I hated as a child (out of a can).

country:
None
text:
Made the following changes based on other reviews:
Change 1 c white sugar to: 1/2 c white + 1/2 c brown sugar
Add 1 t orange zest
Add 1/2 t cinnamon

Cook for 20 minutes to make it thicker.  Mash with a potato masher a few times while boiling.

*Good on oatmeal for breakfast and as a turkey sandwich spread :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this today for tomorrow's supper (as per a few people's suggestion to make ahead to give the OJ time to mellow). I taste tested it today however and I thought it was very tasty! Very tart, very sweet, but that's how I like my cranberry sauce. I do hope that it thickens up more by tomorrow. When I put it in the fridge it was a little runny. I followed recipe exactly, and had set a timer for 10 minutes once I added cranberries. Well I was busy making pecan pie and timer went off and either I didn't hear the popping and something but next I knew it was boiling over! Needless to say I took it off the heat at that point. So keep an eye on this so you don't have a sticky cranberry mess to clean up off your stove!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is so much better than canned cranberry sauce and so easy to make. It's delicious just like it is, or you can easily make changes and add ingredients to suit your taste.  I didn't have orange juice, so I added the juice and zest from an orange and enough water to make a cup. I also replaced half of the sugar with Splenda to cut down the calories.  I made it the day before Thanksgiving to let the flavors develop. It's really good but it's a little too sweet for me, so I chopped up a small tart apple and added that to the leftovers - fabulous!! Next time I make this, I'll use 1/2 cup Splenda and 1/2 cup brown sugar, and maybe add some chopped pecans.

text:
Ive made this three years in a row now for Thanksgiving and its a huge success! However Ive tweaked it. After the cranberries pop I mash them with a mashed potatoes masher. Then i add the following:  1 C. Dole Crushed Pineapple (in 100% juice) after all; 1/2 C. Sugar; and another 1/4 cup orange juice. To me it gives it just the right tart vs sweet balance. And the fam all seem to agree!

text:
I went with the suggestions from folks to split the sugar between brown and white and the OJ with Grand Marnier (I had Gran Gala on hand instead). This cranberry sauce is really good. Enough sweet to cut the tart, but still leave you puckering a little. The Grand Marnier adds a little something extra, but I'm willing to bet the recipe would have been only an eight of a star less grand without these changes if any less at all. Keeping this one on my favorites list!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
So good and so easy to make!  You'll never want to eat canned cranberry sauce again.   This recipe on it's own is 5 stars, and very versatile.  I like to make the following additions: zest and juice 1 orange,  then add water to equal 1 cup liquid, use 1/2 brown & half granulated sugar, and add a dash of cinnamon.  I also decrease the sugar to about 3/4 c. total., and find that I need to cook the sauce for a good 20 minutes to get my desired consistency.

This is amazingly delicious and super quick and easy! I followed someone else's suggestions and made these minor adjustments: 1/2 brown sugar & 1/2 white sugar, added 1/4 tsp of cinnamon and simmered for 20 min rather than 10. The only reason I'm not giving if 5 stars is because I didn't make the recipe exactly as is but it is definit  I was concerned about it being too sweet as some mentioned but I think it is perfect!!

I changed mine too. I used the 2 packages fresh cranberries, 1 cup white and 1 cup brown sugars, juice from one navel orange, 1/4 cup Grand Marinier, 1 peeled and diced green apple, 8oz can crushed pineapple with juice, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon. Cranberry Sauce was always a Thanksgiving afterthought in our family, but this recipe has become a holiday staple for the past several years. Simple, tasty, make it the night before. This recipe is very flexible. Sometimes we cut the sugar in half - it can be a little sweet. We have also substituted half the OJ for Grand Marnier or Cointreau. It is a huge hit.

userID:
5342098
Display Name:
3xkaty

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/707194.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This has been my go-to cranberry sauce recipe for 3 Thanksgivings now. I don't like mine so sweet, so I only use 1/2C of sugar. I also use only 1/2C oj and 1/2C water. It comes out with just the right amount of tart-to-sweet my husband and I like. I've put in 1/2tsp (give or take) of cinnamon during the cooking too and people really seem to like that. If you don't want whole-berry sauce, use a strainer with small holes, put a large bowl under it, and mash the berries with the back of a large spoon, leaving just the liquid and pulp in the bowl. We put some of the remaining skins back in for a little texture.

text:
This recipe is amazing.  I have never made cranberry sauce and this was simple and yummy.  I like mine a little thicker so I used a potato smasher to crush the cranberries and make it thicker without large bits of fruit.  I made it 2 days ahead of time and refrigerated it, and it was so good.
** Note**
I agree with those before me that stated that this recipe does need a pinch of cinnamon.  I tried the sauce before I added the cinnamon, and the cranberry and orange really competed with one another.  The cinnamon takes the edge off of both.

As suggested by others I used 1/2 of the amount of orange juice to keep sauce from being too thin, but then added about 1/8 cup brandy at the end after cooking for about 15 minutes. favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4783949.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is great (4.5 stars) as-is, but some of my family thought the orange flavor was a little strong the first time I made it.

Following the advice of other reviewers, I cut the orange juice in half and used half water. I also substituted brown sugar for half of the white sugar. Those changes mellowed and balanced the flavor, and in my opinion it's a 5-star recipe with those two changes.

The last time I made it, I added 1/4 tsp ground cinnamon, which gave it just a bit more holiday joy. I get lots of compliments (and I have to double the recipe!) when I bring this to family gatherings.

text:
This is far too sweet.  Oddly enough, though, once it cooled ( I let it sit in the fridge overnight) it wasn't as sweet as when I had my husband try it (day of). He has a huge sweet tooth, so I thought he wouldn't mind,  but  even he said it was " like sugar punching you in the face". I tried adding water, about a cup and a half and reheating it. I don't know if the heat just broke down the sugar even more, but it didn't really help. I think this might make a great jam on toast, but not as an accompaniment to a meat dish. 

If I were to do this again, I would just add a 1/3 cup of brown sugar, 1/3 of orange juice, and about a cup of water.

Super simple and tastes great!  I've been making this for the past several years now, no more canned sauce for us.  I may try adding some additional spices at some point, but I really like the pure tart taste as is.  I do mash the cranberries with the back of a wooden spoon after they pop and soften and then cook long enough for the sauce to thicken.  I usually make this 1-2 days prior to our Thanksgiving meal.  Love it!

text:
After reading most of the reviews....I decided to put on my body armor in order to take on this task.  I followed the recipe, but adjusted the sugar amount due to dietary needs only.  After cranberries were in there for about 10 minutes, I put my helmet on, and started to smash the berries. Yes they will explode somewhat, but if you find they are tender....just go in and smash them.  All kidding aside, this recipe was great.  I will never buy canned cranberry sauce again.

text:
This is the first year I decided to make cranberry sauce. I've had fresh cranberry sauce before and I love it! This recipe was very good and easy to follow. I cooked it a little longer just to make sure that most of the cranberries had popped. The consistency was perfect and it tasted very good! My only complaint is I like the tart taste of the cranberry and it was so sweet it didn't really have that same tartness to it. If you're not usually a cranberry fan, this is probably the recipe for you! I will probably make this again using very little sugar, but keeping the orange juice since I like the flavor it gives! Thank you for sharing!

text:
I loved this recipe! No need to add anything else to it. I admit I used frozen cranberries (you try finding them fresh in July) and I did not have time to thaw them beyond the car ride home. If you do the same, the cranberries will need to cook for 25 minutes and they won't pop. They were probably done at 20 minutes but I was hopeful they would pop. I used a potato masher to smush them twice after I removed from the heat. Jelled up beautifully as it cooled and was very fragrant.

I have made this 3 times.  1.  followed the recipe exactly, except I substitute 3/4 cup of Agave  (I like Amber) since we use very little white sugar (3/4 C Agave=1 C White sugar).  2.  I added chopped apple (great) and 3.  I added chopped apple and chopped walnuts.  Depends on what you like . I cool a little and then put in the refrigerator , lightly  covered , until I use it.  Terrific recipe.  Gail

text:
I read the reviews and took Liza's advice.  I used 1/2 cup orange juice, 1/2 cup pineapple juice and 1 cup sugar.  Dissolved.  Then added 1 6-oz. container of raspberries - cooked until I could mush with a fork.  Then added 1/4 cup grand marinier and I also added a few dashed of cinnamon.  I also roasted chopped pecans with butter in a skillet instead of raw pecans.  Taste wonderful after a few days in fridge.  Very good - will make again.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a wonderful recipe!! Normally we do cranberry jelly by oceanspray, yes the canned kind. This year I was hosting twelve people and wanted something fresh. It was a delicious sweet and tangy hit!  I doubled the recipe but made some slight changes. I used 1/2 water and 1/2 orange juice  (naked orange juice) instead of only orange juice. I also added a 1/4 extra sugar. I added these things to get a good balance of sweet and tangy. I also put everything in the pot at once, brought it to a boil for about 3 minutes and then let it simmer for close to twenty minutes, until all the berries have popped, stirring during the entire process. My goal was a thicker sauce, and it does thicken as it cools. My advice is to make this the night before you need it and it seems to thicken overnight as well in yhe refrigerator.

Very easy recipe and quick. But I found that it was just a tad too tart for my taste and was reluctant to add more sugar. Instead I cut the sugar to 3/4 cups and added about 1/2 cup of fresh blueberries, mashed everything a little and cooked for two minutes more to thicken just a little bit more.  Everyone loved it.  This is the only way I will ever make cranberry sauce again.

text:
I've been making my own for years, and this is pretty-much the way I do it!

One cup of each ingredient per bag makes it easy to scale up. I filled mason jars with it one year and gave them out as gifts one year. 

I mash the cranberries with a fork or spoon while they're cooking and the texture is great. As far as the thickness I like mine cold so I refrigerate it for a few hours or overnight if I cook it the day before. Thickens up just just fine.

3/4 c  orange juice
1/4 c water

1/4 tsp cinnamon

userID:
16513638
Display Name:
Kathryn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe and it tastes like oranges. NOT cranberries. I even reduced the sugar by half to try to cut out some of the sweetness I knew would be there from the orange juice. When I realized it was total loss I added some orange zest (why not at this point), a shot of brandy and a half teaspoon of freshly grated ginger. I let it cool. Made some sweet dough for my coffee cake recipe and layered the dough, the sauce and then another layer of dough and then a crumble topping. Bisquick makes a good coffee cake dough if your in a pinch, just add some sugar, an egg and milk until you get a thick but sticky dough. Spray or grease your pan and viola! Coffee cake. I'll follow the age old recipe from Ocean Spray for my sauce this year. It is always reliable and a dash of orange zest won't ruin it like the juice in this recipe did. Had I not been able to rescue this cranberry sauce by using it to fill a coffee cake I would have given it a 1 star rating. I hope this helps.

text:
This is a great recipe, just with some tweaks. Instead of using orange juice, I used half apple cider and half water, so it wouldn't be so sweet. Because my family doesn't like any chunks, I took an immersion blender to it when the cranberries had popped. It is very smooth and jelly like now. I will definitely make it for Thanksgiving!

text:
I have made this as is and it is wonderful.  But I was feeling adventurous one day and I added the flesh of 1/2 orange and the rind of one orange for an extra orange kick.  I think I also slightly reduced the sugar in this one.  If you find you have it too sweet, you can always add a little lemon to try to balance it out, or cook a small amount of cranberries with just water and mix the together with your sweetened ones.

This cranberry sauce is so good you can eat it as a dessert! I've been making it for thanksgiving for the last 5 years. Changes I've made over the years: add a little more sugar (about 2 extra TBLSPN), cook with 2 cinnamon sticks (remove after cooking) and I simmer the cranberries for about 30 min. I pop the unpopped berries and chill overnight prior to thanksgiving dinner.

I used a whole bag of cranberries to 1 cup orange juice, but slightly cut back the amount of sugar to about 3/4 cup or so, using half brown sugar and half white, due to other reviews mentioning that the orange juice would already have sugar. When I was done, I mashed it with a potato masher a bit. I loved it. Tangy and sweet. My 3-year old grandson was coaxed into tasting it on the tip of his tongue, and ended up dipping turkey and bread into it enthusiastically.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I have the recipe with a slight change.  Instead of orange juice I use a whole tangerine cut in half and then halved again into quarters.  I take out all seeds and put this with the cranberries in a pan and add a little water and 3/4 cup sugar.  Mix well.  Cook on med./low until the cranberries are very soft and popping.  I then remove the tangerine quarters and squeeze the remain juice into the sauce.  Works every time.  Quick and flavorful.  No more canned for me.

userID:
10323215
Display Name:
Lara Mason
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4105729.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fantastic. I tried it for the first time today.  I used 1/2c white sugar and 1/2 cup brown. I fresh squeezed an orange which gave me 2/3 cup and I filled the rest of the cup with water, and a sprinkling of cinnamon.  First after a couple hours cold it didn't gel right so I put it back in the pot and added 2 heaping tablespoons of brown sugar and a couple slices of an apple. I also stirred in pecans. I cooked longer at a boil continuously stirring and it gelled up nicely. It's still chilling but it looks great. The extra pectin from the apple and thickening from the extra brown sugar helped. I will never buy canned again!
Review:
Rating:

This is a good recipe!  Next time I will make a few changes.  We love cranberry sauce in our home.  Initially this recipe was not well received by the expert - my husband!  But as it sits for a day it gets better.  It has been voted THE BEST CRANBERRY SAUCE EVER by all Thanksgiving guests :)

text:
Turned out pretty good but was a little too sweet for my taste.  I made it exactly as written.  The "orangeyness" was perfect for me and the texture was great, really gelled.  I read some other reviewers mention that the sugar is what makes it gel so I imagine that in order to get the sweetness down I may need to sacrifice some of the thickness but I think it would be worth it.  I think I could always cut the sugar in half and then thicken if needed with corn starch.

text:
This was a great recipe! Every year I make homemade cranberry sauce but haven't stuck to one recipe yet because they were all missing "something". I think I found it in this one! I read other reviews and used 1/2 cup of oj and 1/2 cup of water, 1/2 cup of brown sugar and 2 T of truvia which is equivalent to 1/2 cup of regular sugar. Lastly I added 2 pinches of ground cinnamon near the end of cooking which brought it all together. Overall I got several compliments and I'm using this one from now on. It's not too sweet and not too tart..just perfect!

text:
This recipe is decent as is, but it definitely did not have a complexity of flavor I was looking for, and I wanted to step it up. I added 1 cinnamon stick, several ground cloves, 1/2 tsp of fresh ginger, 1/8th tsp nutmeg, 1 star anise, a dash of vanilla, juice and rind of one lemon, rind of one orange, 1 C chopped walnuts, 1/2 C raisins, 1/4 C Grand Mariner. After those additions was it truly orgasmic.

userID:

Display Name:
Julia West
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4129780.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fantastic! My first time ever making cranberry sauce, and the family LOVES it (after 22 years of serving the canned jelly type)!  This is a super-easy and quick recipe, though I recommend you refridgerate the sauce if you like it thick.
I read several reviews and modified the recipe a little based on their comments and our tastes. Instead of 1 cup OJ, I used 1/2 cup OJ and 1/2 cup no sugar lemonaid; Minute Maid Light 15 Calorie. This reduced the sweetness and added a bit of the tart back.  I also added 1/2 tsp each cinnamon and nutmeg to the sugar/juice combo, bringing it to bubble before adding the cranberries.  I stirred frequently while the berries were popping and then lightly mashed the mixture with my potato masher after removing the pan from the heat. Once it reached a simi-thick consistancy from cooling, I put it into the fridge overnight.  Total hit at dinner!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Pretty good and easy to make. I cut sugar to a litle bit more than 3/4. I also use 3/4 cup of freshly squeezed orange juice (2 medium oranges make about 1 cup juice), plus 1/4 cup of Triple Sec after the sauce starts to boil. After I turn the heat off, I grate some orange zest. A side note. Craberries really pop!

11/26/15 Update Note: this year I spiced it up a little bit by cooking the sauce with 1/4 tsp of cinnamon, 1/4 tsp of allspice, 1/8 tsp of ginger, and 1/8 tsp of clove. . I also add 1/2 of pomegranate. It has a lot of potential.

userID:
6696295
Display Name:
Pam F.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
46
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined several of the helpful hints: 2 bags Cranberries, 2 cups OJ, 3/4 cup dark brown sugar (packed), 3/4 cup Natural Cane Sugar, 1/4 tsp Cinnamon.  Heat/dissolve sugars/cinnamon in OJ, add Cranberries and cook until it starts to thicken (about 30 minutes).  I made it the day before and it was GREAT!  The hint of cinnamon was just enough to perk your senses but you couldn't really taste it.  Cooking the cranberries should be anywhere from when they just start popping (about 10 minutes) to when they thicken depending on the desired consistency.  I have never cared for whole cranberries and have always had jellied.  This year no one ate the jellied cranberries!  Pam F.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for Thanksgiving, first time I tried making Cranberry sauce and it was excellent!  Even the kids liked it!  I used Xagave brand of agave nectar and used about 3/4 of a cup instead of sugar to make it a bit healthier and it tastes great!  I also added a bit of cinnamon and just a tiny bit of nutmeg per other reviews.  I will definitely make this again and probably never buy the canned stuff again!  REALLY, REALLY good and VERY easy to make!  I did make it about two days ahead of time, too, to cut down on work the day of and some reviews mentioned that the flavor gets better when made ahead of time... great idea!  Was still very tart even with the o.j., but I did use Great Value (Wal-Mart) brand that is a pretty sour o.j. so that may have helped.  Overall it did not seem too sweet, but was comparable to the canned stuff, just better and much healthier with the agave nectar.

None
text:
As an experienced cook, I was a little concerned with the simplicity of this recipe, however it turned out GREAT !  I reduced the sugar to a little under half, used fresh squeezed juice, and let it simmer under a watchful eye! Like other reviewers, I used a potato masher to mash the cranberries. Everyone loved it, even those who typically do not like whole cranberry sauce.  You can push it through a seive using the back of a large spoon if you want a more jelly like sauce.  This is more time consuming and reduces the recipe to half what you cooked.  Using this recipe, there is no need to buy canned sauce.

text:
This is a great recipe; it's just a little sweet for my taste. I gave it 4 stars because I did make some changes. I use 3/4 cup pineapple orange juice + 1/4 cup water, 3/4 cup sugar, 3 tablespoons light brown sugar, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon and a dash of ground cloves. I also add the juice of half a lemon and some zest and cook it longer. It lightens it up a bit.

text:
Great recipe! I didn't have orange juice, so I used 1/2 C water and cut the sugar in half (using 1/4 C white and 1/4 C brown). I tasted it while it was cooling, and thought it needed a little zip, so I stirred in about a tablespoon or so of "Mighty Mango" Naked Juice. Now it's amazing! Before the mango juice, my daughter (who doesn't like cranberry sauce) said it was "ok", but now she loves it! I might need to make another batch!

text:
I just made this...2 batches actually.  Having read the reviews after I made and tasted the first batch (followed exactly as written), it was a tad too sweet for me.

The second batch, I made, I only decreased the sugar to 3/4 cup, some might want to go to 1/2 cup of sugar.  The second batch was perfect for my tastes.  I did cook the second batch for 13 minutes.  

All in all...EXCELLENT recipe.  Simple, flavorful and many thanks for sharing!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did alter it a bit, however. 

Used 3/4 cup sugar rather than 1 full cup.

Used a cup of water rather than a cup of orange juice.

Added the processed fruit of one large navel orange, and the processed peel of 1/4 of that same orange. The orange fruit adds back flavor, the peel adds a bit of bite and consistency.

Once the cranberries started popping, I used a handheld processor to blend the mix right in the pan. Then simmered for another 15 minutes or so so that the mixture cooked down. 

My wife, who despises cranberry sauce, loved it! As did my daughter, and me, too. We all plan to use it on the turkey.

text:
I just made this today for Thanksgiving tomorrow. It is fantastic. I can't help licking the ladle. Yum! Thanks for the great recipe and to all the reviewers who helped enhance it.
I used 14 oz. of fresh cranberries. I also used 3/4 cup orange juice and added 1/4 cup Grand Marnier to it. I reduced the sugar by half. It was tart and plenty sweet for me. I used 1/4 cup brown sugar and 1/4 cup white sugar. Added 1/4 teaspoon of cinnamon and voila! The best cranberry sauce ever. Last year, I had made a fancy cranberry sauce with port wine ($$) etc. and I just didn't want to spend so much money and energy on something this simple and delicious.
