text:
This is the BEST cranberry sauce I've EVER had! I made it with with a few adjustments. I took the advice of another reviewer and added Grand marnier, 1/4 cup per 12 oz. cranberries and cut the orange juice to 3/4 cup per 12 oz. cranberries.(I doubled the recipe). I aslo added the zest of one lemon to the orange juice, sugar, grand marnier mixture. After adding the cranberries, I added about a half cup of candied orange peel, I made them especially for this recipe. I think I have died and gone to HEAVEN! I can't wait for Thanksgiving this year, if it is this good now, I can only imagine what it will taste like after having a day or 2 to set up in the fridge :)

This is a great recipe with a lot of true cranberry flavor with hints of sweet and tart all mixed deliciously. I have made this recipe in its original portions and also made using Allrecipes change serving feature for about 100 people. Both times this simple recipe came out fantastic and everyone enjoyed it! For the larger portion I did add a little bit more Sugar and Orange juice to compensate for the longer time on the stove, still in equal portions, and it was still delicious! It also freezes well for future meal use, so it is a great make ahead dish!

text:
I did the suggestions of using some oranges crushed and half brown sugar and cooking longer to get it thicker. Wonderful...I lucked up on a deal on fresh cranberries last year making them cheaper than canned sauce so I bought enough for this year as well and they freeze wonderfully and since the low water content keeps them from getting soggy they are just like fresh.  My immediate family loves this as it is but my Dad is a die hard canned jellied sauce lover so I took half the recipe and added a can of jellied to it blending it well and my father practically inhaled it at a special Father's Day dinner so it is another new addition to this Thanksgiving menu.

Dana

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful Recipe!!  I made jelled cranberries instead of sauce.  I made as is, using all white sugar.  I added two small shakes of cinnamon to the orange juice, sugar mixture.  I brought that to a boil, added the cranberries and boiled for 20 minutes.  At about 15 minutes, I mashed the cranberries in the pan.  At the end of the 20 minutes, I strained the mashed mixtured through a mesh strainer.  Using the back of a wooden spoon, I pressed the berries against the mesh strainer and continued to scrape off the pulp that came through into the bowl underneath.  I repeated this until I was left with little more than the skins in the strainer.  I covered my bowl of strained cranberries and refrigerated for about 30-45 min.  Excellent!

text:
Excellent!! Normally I hate it when people change a recipe then give it a rating based upon the changes but since others have already suggested changes, I feel free to offer my own. I, too, used 1/2 cup orange juice, 1/2 cup water, 1 cup white sugar, and since we like it sweet I added 1/2 brown sugar. I also cooked this with 2 small cinnamon sticks which I removed when done. One word of caution. DO NOT LEAVE THIS while cooking. As another reviewer warned--I should have listened. I put it on the stove with a lid on, turned the burner on and as it started to heat, I left the room for not more than 90 seconds! When I returned it had boiled all over my stove!  But the final product was excellent. I will make this from now on. No more canned stuff. Thanks

Yummy nummy yum!  I don't like cranberry sauce - well, I can't really say that. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I dissolved about 2/3 cup Splenda in 1 cup of orange juice.  I then added a 10 oz package of frozen cranberries and let them simmer for about 15 minutes.  Taking other reviews into consideration, I used a potato masher to mash the cranberries.  Finally, I mixed a heaping spoonful of cornstarch with an additional 1/3 cup of orange juice and added that to thicken the sauce and shot a squeeze of lime juice in too.  I use the sauce as a spread for sandwiches.  It's fantastic!

text:
I hadn't made cranberry sauce before as my parents had always bought it in the can, and they usually forgot about it until mid-meal. Anyway this Christmas I decided to try this recipe and my family absolutely loved it. It's so easy to make. I added 2 cinnamon sticks. Watch that you don't let your pot boil over - it's a messy clean up if you don't catch it in time! I let this cool completely to thicken up and then heat it up just before dinner time. I'll definitely make this again.

text:
I was rather worried about trying whole cranberry sauce because I know cranberries are very tart and untasty by themselves, but NEVER AGAIN will I go back to canned cranberry sauce!  I doubled the recipe, followed some advice and did half brown, half white sugar and used orange, pineapple and a tbsp. lemon juice and it was PERFECT.  My pop added the peel of an orange, and a cinnammon stick overnight and removed right before serving.  The flavors were tangy, sweet, subtle, and undeniably harvesty.  It wasn't bitter and it was EVEN BETTER with turkey leftovers days later.  Cranberries are so cheap and plentiful at this time of year, everyone should at least TRY this recipe.  :)

text:
This is very similar to the recipe I have used for a long time. Instead of orange juice I use water pretty much follow the directions given. I prefer a softer version of cranberry sauce and by cooking less time[8-10 mins] I have a softer sauce. Less pectin is released and for my tastes, this is just perfect! Love it on leftover turkey [open-faced] sandwiches.  Once I made fresh cranberry sauce, I decided it definitely has a much better taste and we prefer that.

text:
I normally do not care for cranberry sauce but I love this recipe! I ended up using half fresh orange juice and half apple juice, due to my lack of oranges in the house. Added some orange zest and a sprinkle of cinnamon. Yum! I also mashed it in a sieve when it had cooled a bit. I just haven't graduated to whole cranberry sauce. This technique worked great as it made the sauce a nice balance between whole cranberry sauce and jellied cranberry sauce.

The flavor was fantastic, though I did add a small amount of nutmeg and cinnamon due to personal preference.  My only qualm is that the directions say to remove the sauce pan after the cranderries start to pop.  I did this, but I think I should have left it on longer. text:
I was asked to bring cranberry sauce for this year's dinner. I don't even like cranberry sauce. The only change I made was to cook it a little longer for thickening purposes...about 15 minutes. This is absolutely delicious!!!!!
Update: made this again this year by request. This time I double the batch, only used about 1 and 2/3 cups of sugar, and added 2 tablespoons of home made applesauce (for the cinnamon/spice content and also thickening) and a generous splash each of brandy and triple sec. I added the last two after I took it off the heat, but the brandy was a little overpowering so I put it back on the heat for about 10 minutes. Cooling now and thickening nicely. YUM.

Wow! This is great! I never have really been into cranberry sauce, but I have to say this is so yummy! A little goes a long way. I made it 2 days ahead of time for Thanksgiving as one review said it froze nicely. I will make this a tradition with my daughters to make every year. My friends nor I have  been fond of the jellied tradition, but it palys an important part of Turkey day so I made it. I didn't have any regular oragne juice, so i used a pineapple/ orange blend which turned out great. it took about 10 minutes total to make, and i let it cool for a minute before taking a fork to smack the pulp. At first I though to take the cranberry skin out, but it was tender and gave the sauce more consistency. I would make this again!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I grew up with the jellied cranberry sauce -- it came to the Thanksgiving table still shaped like the can.  After I got married, my New England Yankee mother-in-law insisted that the cranberries had to be freshly cooked for Thanksgiving dinner.  So I've been using this recipe for years and it's simply the best!  It's both sweet and tart with that fresh burst of cranberry flavor.  If you want to bring out the orange flavor, you can add a little orange zest.  You can also add nuts at the start of cooking -- walnut or pecan pieces or slivered almonds -- if you want to add some extra texture.
